para.text: In addition to duties the Mayor prescribes, the DCIA shall:

Provide occupational skills training ("skills training") annually in industries for which there is significant demand regionally or by a major employer, including construction, infrastructure, and information technology;
Provide occupational skills training designed to meet the needs of employers by:
Aligning skills training, where appropriate, with the annual recommendations the committees submit to the DCIA pursuant to § 32-247(c);
Submitting a proposed curriculum, at least 30 calendar days prior to the start of any skills training taught by DCIA staff, to the relevant committee for its feedback; and
Taking into consideration any feedback from a committee when implementing any skills trainings taught by DCIA staff;

Submitting to the relevant committee, at least 30 calendar days before soliciting applications or bids on a grant or contract to provide skills training, a request that the committee review a grant or contract solicitation's proposed scope of work; and
Considering any feedback received from a committee when preparing statements of work for grants and contracts to provide skills training; and

For any customized skills training provided specifically for a particular employer, seeking input from the employer consistent with the requirements outlined in subparagraphs (B) and (C) of this paragraph;

Provide test preparation sessions and practice exams to ready participants to obtain the occupational credentials the committees identify in their annual reports pursuant to § 32-247(c)(4) [§ 32-247(b)]; and

Provide job referrals, as defined in 20 C.F.R. § 651.10, to employers in the industry sectors in which training is offered pursuant to paragraph (1) of this subsection for all qualified graduates of DCIA training programs.
DCIA skills training may include:
Training services enumerated in section 134(c)(3)(D) of the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act, approved July 22, 2014 (128 Stat. 1529; 29 U.S.C. § 3174(c)(3)(D));
Supportive services, as defined in 20 C.F.R. § 651.10;
Integrated education and training, as defined in 34 C.F.R. § 463.35;
Workforce preparation activities, as defined in 34 C.F.R. § 463.34; and
Job development, as defined in 20 C.F.R. § 651.10.

At least 66% of the participants receiving skills training through the DCIA each fiscal year shall be trained in occupations that pay an average wage that is at least 150% of the minimum wage specified in § 32-1003.
At least 25% of the value of each grant or contract with a skills training provider shall be contingent on the provider achieving at least one of the following results:
At least 75% of the provider's participants receive an industry-recognized credential; and
At least 80% of the provider's participants enter permanent, unsubsidized employment in the occupation of training.
